RECLAMATION
(PULAU BRANI AND BRANI SHOAL)


2.35 p.m.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move the motion standing in my name,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with section 4 of the Foreshores Act (Chapter 270), approves the reclamation by Government of those portions of the foreshores at Pulau Brani and Brani Shoal containing a total area of approximately 116 acres as shown coloured in orange on the plan marked "LAND OFFICE RECLAMATION PLAN NO. 2/72" which is deposited in the Land Office, Singapore.

    Sir, Pulau Brani which has been allocated for use by the Port of Singapore Authority and MINDEF (Ministry of Defence), as indicated on the plan marked "LAND OFFICE RECLAMAXTION PLAN NO. 2/72", a copy of which is displayed in the Library of this House for the information of Members, is being developed to provide the following facilities:

    (a) coastal wharves for MINDEF Maritime Command;

    (b) coastal wharves for the Port of Singapore Authority;

Column: 873



    (c) an oil tank farm for storage and bunkering; and

    (d) other uses that may be compatible with the above.

For the purpose of the development, it is necessary to reclaim about 86 acres of the foreshore at Pulau Brani and about 30 acres at Brani Shoal, as shown coloured orange on the plan.

    The reclamation will be carried out by the Port of Singapore Authority, as agent of the Government, at an estimated cost of $29.2 million and is expected to be completed within two years. The necessary fill for the proposed reclamation will be obtained from the high land at Pulau Brani within the area now being developed by MINDEF and will also be obtained from the dredging of the nearby channels and from the Sister Shoals, which are scheduled to be removed to widen the existing navigational channel and to do away with obstructions to shipping.

    On completion of the reclamation, the reclaimed land will be proclaimed as State land and will, thereafter, be alienated to the Port of Singapore Authority on terms and conditions to be agreed with the Land Office.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Parliament, in accordance with section 4 of the Foreshores Act (Chapter 270), approves the reclamation by Government of those portions of the foreshores at Pulau Brani and Brani Shoal containing a total area of approximately 116 acres as shown coloured in orange on the plan marked "LAND OFFICE RECLAMATION PLAN NO. 2/72" which is deposited in the Land Office, Singapore.

    Head 1301 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*.(* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, last week when I took part in the debate on the Budget presented by the Minister, I mentioned that it was a progressive Budget, which would benefit the development of our commerce and industry. Today, I still hold this point of view, and that is, that the Minister for Finance has prepared a healthy and progressive Budget. What I would like to raise here is the question of the various provisions and whether they are adequately allocated. On 7th March, when the Minister presented the Budget in this House, he emphasised that the main reason why it has not been necessary to increase taxes over the last three years was because of the rapid development of our commerce and industry leading to an increase in revenue.

    Sir, I would like to touch upon the provisions for the various departments. I think there are certain areas which we need to discuss and examine. The total provision amounted to the figure of $1,448,692,350. In terms of the various departments, the allocation for Defence and Internal Security is 38.9 per cent. This is necessary in order to strengthen our defence and to maintain our internal security. Social Services accounted for 26.6 per cent, Statutory Expenditure accounted for 15.1 per cent, and Economic Services accounted for only 7.8 per cent. What I would like to raise here is in regard to Economic Services. 7.8 per cent appears to me as rather low. The Minister himself has mentioned that the increase in revenue is due

Column: 875

to the rapid development of our commerce and industry, and these Economic Services are beneficial to economic expansion and industrial and commercial development. Therefore, we should have adequate provision for Economic Services. If we compare Economic Services to the goose that lays the golden egg, then we should provide adequate nutrition for this goose. It is only by providing adequate nutrition that this goose can be expected to lay a great quantity of golden eggs, so that we can have better results in our economic expansion. Otherwise, this goose, suffering from malnutrition, will be sickly and contract a lot of diseases. If this is the case, I believe we will not be able to get any eggs from this goose. Mr Speaker, Sir, it is for this reason that I believe the provision for Economic Services is inadequate and, therefore, should be increased. In addition, I would like to ask the Minister to explain the details related to Economic Services.

    The second point I would like to raise is in regard to external trade. Last year, our trade deficit has increased to the phenomenal amount of $3,000 million. The Minister for Finance explained to us last year that we do not have to worry unduly about trade deficit because this can be offset by incomes received from other sources, such as ship repairing, port services, and tourism. I would like to know whether the $3,000 million trade deficit last year has been sufficiently set off by the incomes from other sources. Can the Minister please explain to this House?

    The third point I would like to mention is in regard to the stability of price levels. The Minister has already acknowledged that there is an increase in the general level of prices. Therefore, I think he should take adequate measures to control prices to ensure a better standard of living for everyone.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, since the Prime Minister has announced the "13th month salary" for civil servants, I presume they are quite satisfied with it. I wonder whether the Minister for Finance will also consider giving the "13th month salary" to pensioners who had put in many years of loyal and patriotic service to the Republic.

    Sir, it is the practice in some departments to retain the services of retired civil servants. This has caused a lot of frustration among junior officers, because they feel that their chances of promotion are nullified by these retired civil servants who are re-employed in some of the senior posts. I am not objecting to their re-employment, but whether their experience is necessary for the betterment of the civil service.

    Sir, there is a certain amount of brain drain among the civil servants who, after having received their scholarships, come back only to resign after serving for a few years. This form of brain drain must be stopped, because the civil servants make use of the civil service as a stepping stone for their own betterment. We cannot have them holding the civil service by the throat.

    However, I would suggest that better conditions of service should be considered for the civil servants. As far as possible, the gap in pay between the public and private sectors should be narrowed, and so prevent a brain drain in the civil service. Furthermore. I would suggest that civil servants should be recruited on a contract basis, so that the knowledge and experience that they gain will not be lost to the

Column: 877

Government after a short employment. Otherwise, it would be a waste of Government expenditure to recruit and train these people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether a varying scale of a maximum of three annual increments in the various salary scales can be granted to an officer for any one year. Entitlement to this special increment should depend on the merits and capabilities of the individual. It will be an incentive for the officers to give of their best.

    As far as the low income group is concerned, I have the greatest sympathy for them. There have been complaints about the rising cost of living in Singapore, although the Minister for Finance is making every effort to bridge the gap between the lower and higher income groups by way of tax reliefs which he has announced in Parliament last week. However. I still feel that the lower income group should get more benefits in the revision of their emoluments, and I hope the National Wages Council will look into this matter.

    Sir, one example of dissatisfaction in the civil service can be seen in the case of temporary officers engaged on a month-to-month basis. Sometimes they are asked to act in a senior post. However, when a vacancy for the senior post is advertised, these officers are unfortunately not eligible to apply. Some other officers, with whom the temporary officers are familiar, will take over the post. Why cannot these temporary officers be confirmed as permanent officers in their senior posts? Can the Minister look into it and rectify the matter?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our local population has a prejudice against locally-made products. This is justified to a great extent. If one were to import a certain product which is also produced locally, a certain difference in quality can be noticed. For example, a certain brand of tooth-paste made in Malaysia foams better in the mouth than the tooth-paste of the same brand produced locally. Similarly, cars manufactured and

Column: 878

assembled by the parent company overseas are of a superior quality to cars of the same make but assembled locally.. Surely something can be done by local manufacturers who produce goods of a certain quality for local consumption and of another quality for export purposes.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am obliged to the Member for Sembawang for his comments and sentiments for adequate provision for the Economic Services and, in particular, industrial development with which I must fully agree. He has asked for some details regarding the allocation for Economic Services. May I refer him to Appendix F of the Main Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure for 1972-73, in which a very detailed breakdown is given of expenditure by functional classification. It will be observed that all the departments and Ministries involved in providing economic services have been allocated adequate funds for their needs. As I have explained in the Budget Statement, the apparent reduction in the provision for Economic Services is due to the fact that the Telecommunications Department is to become a statutory authority and, therefore, no provision has been made for its recurrent expenditure which was allocated a sum of $19.4 million in the 1971-72 Estimates. If this is taken into account, it will be observed that the provision for Economic Services has, in fact, been increased from $107.5 million in 1971-72 to $113.14 million in 1972-73. I should also like to remind the Member that the amount we have entered in the Ordinary Estimates does not constitute all the budgetary provision for Economic Services, as provision is also made in the Development Estimates for expenditure on Economic Services. It should also be noted that with the increased allocation for Defence and Social Services, the proportionate share of the expenditure for Economic Services would tend to be marginally smaller, even when the actual quantum of funds provided has been increased. I can assure the Member that adequate

Column: 879

funds will always be made available for departments providing economic services, and that there is no intention on the part of the Treasury to curtail their expenditure.

    The Member for Sembawang has also asked a question on the widening trade gap of $3,283.7 million in 1971 as compared with $2,778.0 million in 1970. This should give no cause for alarm. The preliminary figures for the 1971 balance of payments show that we have some $847.5 million in our favour compared with $416.5 million for 1970. This represents a 103 per cent increase in our reserves. Some reasons for the trends in the balance of payment figures had been given in the 1970 and 1971 Budget debates. If I may summarise, it should be appreciated that the widening trade gap is fairly common in a developing country, owing to the need to purchase large amounts of capital goods, particularly heavy machinery and transportation equipment. Of the trade gap of $3,283.7 million in 1971, import of machinery and transportation equipment alone accounted for $2,209.1 million. Even if we discount the $740.5 million for export of machinery and transportation equipment from Singapore, the retained imports still amounted to $1,568.0 million.

    The other point which has to be made is that the trade balance is not the only factor in the balance of payments. It is offset by increased invisible earnings from, firstly, entrepot trade services, including finance, banking, insurance and freight earnings. Secondly, unrecorded purchases by tourists and transportation personnel, such as ship and air crew. Thirdly, ship building, ship repairing, supplies to vessels, oil rigs and aircraft using Singapore as a base. Fourthly, the substantial under-coverage by the trade balance figures, which is indicated by the large balancing item of $3,045.2 million in our balance of payments balance sheet. Some redistribution of these balancing items could be attempted and would be largely made on the credit side of the Current Account, particularly on

Column: 880

merchandise trade, also on Capital Account. This attempt to redistribute the balancing items has not been made since comprehensive data on these flows are not available to enable this to be done on a reliable basis. Nevertheless, I think it would be healthy to see our exports increase substantially. Singapore's total exports in 1971 registered a 13 per cent increase over the 1970 performance. In addition to the introduction of the Economic Expansion Incentives (Relief from Income Tax) Act, a new export promotion unit is being set up in the Trade Division in 1972-73 to undertake studies of export markets and to take full advantage of the preferential treatment offered by various developed countries to assist developing countries to increase exports of locally manufactured goods.

    On the Member's last comment on the matter of price increases, the Government is doing what it can to stabilise the prices of foodstuffs, especially basic necessities. Manufacturers, importers, and members of the distributive trade have been warned against taking undue advantage of any situation that presents itself to jack up prices. In this respect, I think officers of the Supplies Office are continually checking on prices of foodstuffs in all localities in Singapore. However, Singapore cannot remain totally immune to changes in supply and demand for food in the international scene. Nevertheless, the Government has to step in to help the consumers wherever possible.

3.00p.m.

    The retail price of locally refined sugar has remained stable at 39 cents a katty, or $550 a ton ex-factory, with duty, since February last year, despite the fact that world prices of raw sugar have shot up from œ49 or $360 per ton to over œ90 or $661.50 per ton currently -- I think it will be appreciated that there has been concern in other countries over the rise in the price of their sugar. To safeguard the consumers in Singapore, an export control is also placed on locally refined sugar.

Column: 881



    As far as wheat flour is concerned, the retail price of 25 cents per katty has remained stable since the beginning of 1971. Rice prices have also remained very firm. Since January last year, wholesale prices for the two Thai top-grade rice have declined from $33.50 and $26 per picul to its present price of $32 and $25 per picul respectively. The price of China top-grade rice has also dropped during the same period from $26.25 to the present value of $23.50 per picul.

    On condensed milk, the price of popular brands has remained at 60 cents for a 14-ounce tin since September last year. Over this period, the prices of raw materials have gone up considerably. Skimmed milk prices have increased on an average of $1,000 to $1,200 a ton, while butter fat prices have risen from $2,400 to $3,300 a ton. The Government has, therefore, done a fair amount of work in trying to stabilise the prices of basic commodities. However, I welcome the establishment last year by the private sector of the Consumers' Association of Singapore, which is very active in looking after the interests of consumers and is working closely with our Trade Division.

    Finally, I understand the National Trades Union Congress is presently studying the feasibility of setting up a Consumers' Co-operative, and that a pilot project will be launched in the near future. With the close co-operation of consumers, this project should prove successful.

    The Member for Anson, first of all, raised the point of the 13th monthly salary to be paid to pensioners. I think the intention of the scheme is really .a 13th month salary payment. So it is not a 13th month pension. In the circumstances, it does not fall within the scope of the 13th month salary scheme or the non-pensionable annual allowance.

    The Member also made some comment on the question of terms and conditions of service for civil servants and, particularly, for those who have just returned from overseas. I believe

Column: 882

his comment is prompted by concern over the possible resignation of civil servants to join the private sector. The present practice, of course, is that the Public Service Commission appoints higher level personnel, including professional and technical personnel, to the permanent establishment so as to offer them a long-term career in the civil service. The Member suggested offering contracts. A small number of officers have been appointed on a temporary basis because they so prefer it. In other cases, it is because they are required for specific projects of a temporary nature only. However, such temporary officers with proven ability have been and will be offered permanent appointment if they wish. Those who were appointed initially on a temporary basis because their jobs were only temporary jobs can apply when permanent vacancies arise. The policy of the P.S.C, is to conduct frequent promotion exercises so that outstanding and promising officers will obtain accelerated promotion.

    Promotion in the professional services is now based on merit rather than for filling posts, so that where there are deserving officers, the P.S.C. will recommend their promotion even though there are insufficient established vacancies. As an added incentive to promising officers, the policy with regard to acting appointments is that these should also be made on merit and not on seniority. Also, pensioners are not normally re-employed unless there are exceptional reasons, such as acute shortage of experienced staff in a particular grade. In every case of re-employment of a pensioner, Government ensures that this is done without depriving the serving officers of their promotion prospects. With near-full employment, it may, in fact, become increasingly necessary to employ more pensioners who are still healthy in mind and body and who can contribute positively to the economy.

    I find it difficult, however, to accept the Member's suggestion to replace the present annual incremental practice with a three-year increment in all cases.

Column: 883



    The Member for Anson also made one comment with regard to locally-made products. I heartily agree that these products should be made more popular among our own consumers. I think the schemes which have been instituted by the Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research should make it plain to all local consumers that our local products are just as good as those which are imported. I hope they will give their full support to the consumption of local products, instead of imported products.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: (Punggol): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1251.

    Sir, in moving this amendment, I would like to refer the Minister for Finance to two Reports which have been presented to this House. One is the Report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1969-70 contained in Paper Cmd. 14 of 1971 presented to Parliament on l7ti July, 1971. The other is the First Report of the Public Accounts Committee contained in Paper Pan. 1 of 1972 presented to Parliament on 12th February, 1972. Sir, whilst browsing through the Auditor- General's Report, I was given the impression that losses of public funds in the various departments were the result of the officials in the departments concerned not being conversant with the financial procedures or that they have been overworked in some cases. The First Report of the Public Accounts Committee bears testimony to this fact. I would like to quote the comments in page 2 of this Report under the heading "Irregularities":

    `8. Perusing the Audit Report your Committee noted the number of irregularities which were, in the main, due to weaknesses

Column: 884

in the accounting system or because the financial officers concerned were not sufficiently acquainted with and did not follow the safeguards laid down in the Instruction Manuals.'

Further down, the Public Accounts Committee made some recommendations, and I quote:

    `9. As an immediate measure, your Committee recommend that attention of all accounting officers should be drawn to these two common areas of weaknesses so that they may be more vigilant and take necessary action to prevent the occurrences or recurrences of such irregularities.

    10. As a long term measure, your Committee feel that the whole problem should be tackled on a wider basis of co-ordination and improvement of general financial administration and supervision, including the use of modern mechanical aids and computers, and that a proper training scheme for officers should be formulated and implemented. For the immediate future, your Committee recommend that the Ministry of Finance look into the feasibility of creating a cadre of trained financial officers at various levels for posting to Ministries and Departments to strengthen financial administration and supervision as well as improve efficiency of financial work in all sectors.'

    Sir, I would like to know whether the Minister for Finance will take immediate remedial action as a result of the two Reports. Of course, I am fully aware that the Public Accounts Committees First Report was presented only last month, lest the Minister should say, "We have just received this First Report and it is now being studied with a view to taking appropriate action as soon as a full evaluation of the Report has been made."

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to take this opportunity to enquire from the Minister for Finance whether his Ministry will consider allowing aided school teachers to apply for holiday bungalows in Changi, which were recently acquired by the Government from the Royal Air Force, on the same terms offered to their counterparts in the Government service?

3.15p.m.

    In making this inquiry, I am prompted by two considerations:

    (1) The recent policy of the Finance Ministry is to allow members of the

Column: 885

public to occupy such bungalows, thus indicating that the availability of holiday bungalows exceeds the needs of civil servants.

    (2) That aided school teachers are granted medical facilities like their counterparts in the Government service. That being so, will they also be granted the same privileges as their counterparts in the Government service?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, regarding the irregularities in the accounting system, whether indicated by the Auditor-General in his Report which has just been received, or whether they are detected by the Ministries or Departments themselves or by the Ministry of Finance, they are always very carefully studied and, where possible, remedies are taken. In any big organisation, however, we must expect that occasional flaws in the accounting system will be discovered. The other area of weakness, which has been suggested as being responsible for losses of public funds, is overworking the staff. On this matter I have, in response to questions in the debate on my annual Budget Statement, stated that the remedy to prevent civil servants from being overworked is to try and retain more of them and to recruit them on a more acceptable basis. On the whole, the Government accounting system is on a firm and sound base. Nevertheless, there is considerable scope for improvement, and steps are being taken to increase the use of computers and other mechanical aids, as suggested by the Member, so that the element of human fallibility can be reduced.

    The other suggestion was that the weaknesses in the accounting system may be due to the unfamiliarity of the financial officers concerned with the proper financial procedures. To remedy this, courses on financial administration are being conducted by the Staff Training Institute for Divisions I and II officers. Subjects on financial system and procedures, annual budgets, financial control, losses of public moneys

Column: 886

and stores, contract and stores procedures are included in the courses conducted by the Institute for administrative and executive officers, and they will continue to be included in future courses.

    The Member for Moulmein asked whether the Finance Ministry will allow aided school teachers to apply for holiday bungalows in Changi. The answer is that they are eligible to apply as members of the public. I believe, however, the suggestion is prompted by the desire to give them priority over other members of the public, in the same way as facilities are given them in the Government hospitals. However, I will look into this matter and, assuming that we have an over-supply of these holiday bungalows, we will certainly consider making them available to the aided school teachers.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1301 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1501.

    Sir, I bring up this matter in order to assure myself of the quality of the goods supplied by the Central Supplies Office. A few months ago when I had occasion to be in hospital for a short time, I was surprised to hear complaints made by senior staff members about an item of furniture, namely, armchairs, supplied by the Central Supplies Office to the Ministry of Health. They were complaints that the item of furniture received showed early signs of deterioration, and on one occasion a chair collapsed under the weight of a patient.

    The question I would like to ask is whether Government departments are forced to accept the goods provided by the Central Supplies Office, even if they are reluctant to accept the goods because they are able to get similar items of equal or better quality and at a cheaper price than those supplied. Is adequate care taken to ensure that the quality of

Column: 887

the goods supplied conform to reasonable expectations of those who place orders for them? In any case, I would imagine also that when orders are placed with the Central Supplies Office, quality specifications are also given. Can the Minister enlighten me on this score?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, all purchases by the Chief Supplies Officer for the requirements of Government departments are made by the open tender system, which ensures that materials supplied are of accepted and specified quality at the most competitive price possible. Wherever possible, samples are examined before the actual purchases are made. It must be recognised that large quantities of supplies are usually consumed and, as public funds should be spent judiciously, they cannot always be of the best quality available. On the other hand, I accept the Member's point that the cheapest are not necessarily the most economical and that mistakes of judgment, which are occasionally made in regard to quality specifications should be corrected by constant review of such specifications. On the particular example of the hospital chair, I am obliged to the Member for the information, and I will ask the Chief Supplies Officer to look into the matter. We cannot guarantee to supply, however, luxury chairs made by Parker Knoll or Eero Saarinen.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, in view of the Minister's reply, I beg leave to withdraw.
